random.line: Emere. You're looking great, as always.
Always the gentleman, aren't you?
Well, in the presence of such a fine lady, one can't help but be eloquent. What brings you here?
I'm wondering how your father's business is going.
Ah, but why talk about that when we can do something far more interesting, such as go for a walk in the local park.
I'm flattered, but I've got things to do.
Suit yourself. I am always available for you.
Good afternoon. Would you care for a cup of tea?
If you are offering...
Wow! It's really good. I love the peach flavor.
It's an imported from Brazil. Squeezed fresh from 100 peaches in an organic farm.
Fancy!

converse.line: Why aren't you succeeding your father's place as heir to the company?
Oh, you ask all but the easy questions! I have no interest in business. I seek to become a poet. I will be like one of the greats, Shakespeare, Frost or Poe. Just you wait!
Do you have any ideas on who will take your place as heir to the company?

I have suggested many to my father, as I feel a little bad leaving with no one to take my place. But, sadly, he has rejected most of them. I thought they would make wonderful replacements, especially my good friend Mao.
She, quite frankly, loves our company. She has been following Lambda Drinks Corporation ever since she was 6. She would me my personal pick for the CEO.
But apparently your father doesn't like her.
That's not it. It's that she doesn't want the position because she feels there is someone better for it out there. I've tried to convince her otherwise, but I guess I am just not persuasive enough.
Where is Mao? I'd like to talk to her.
She lives in Fujita. I can't seem to remember which house, though.
You have convinced Mao! Great! Let's see what my father says...
Ah, Emere. You have come right in the middle of my writing of a new poem. Would you like to hear it so far?

random.line: " The universe is on fire, exploding without flame. We are the lost ones, we are the pioneers. One last brief whisper in our loved ones' ears. To reassure them and to pierce the fear. Standing at controls then still unknown. We told the world we were about to go. "
That's surprisingly dark for someone like you.
I am aware. I love to capture the dark side of life, the part not seen by many.

" In the harsh light of freedom I know that I cannot deny that I have wasted time. I have frittered it away in idle boasts of my freedom and fidelity, when simpler words would have profited me most... I've bogged myself down in the web of talk, quack philosophy and sophistry at physicality I've always baulked. Like the man in the chair who believes it's beyond him to walk. "
Your poetry is strange. Really strange.
I take that as a compliment. I treasure the fact that I write in a radically different way to any thing anyone has seen before.

" Axes shattered, there is no North or South. Far off, the ice is foundering slowly. The ice is turning to water. The water rushes over all. Cities crash in the mighty wave. The final man is very small, plunging in for his final bathe. "
I'm sensing a dark progressive mood from your poems.
That's exactly what I'm going for.
